content.title: What to know about dizziness
paragraphs: People living with chronic disease are more likely to feel dizzy or lightheaded as a symptom of their disease or due to medication side effects.
This can increase the risk of falls and impact daily activities.

content.title: What to do when feeling dizzy
tips: Sit down until the feeling stops
When sitting or standing, move slowly to avoid falls

content.title: How to prevent dizziness and light-headedness
tips: Ensure medication is taken correctly, and speak to a pharmacist, nurse, or doctor about side effects
Check each day for swelling in stomach, feet, ankles, and legsInstead of eating a few large meals, eat several small meals during the day
Sleep with head on a pillow(s)
Avoid very hot places (e.g., hot tubs, hot showers, or baths)
Make sure the home has proper lighting to avoid falls
Have mobility aids (walker, cane, etc.) nearby when standing up

content.title: Dizziness Storysheet
paragraphs: View the Dizziness Storysheet to learn more about what to do when someone is experiencing dizziness.
